facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 457/58 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 457/58. Appeal from the Judgment

facts.text: Appeal from Judgment and order dated September 12, 1956 of Punjab High Court in Letters Patent Appeal No. 38 of 1955.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the Judgment and order dated September 12, 1956, of the Punjab High Court in Letters Patent Appeal No. 38 of 1955.

facts.text: Judgment delivered by MUDHOLKAR, J. on May 4, 1961.

anchor.surface_text: 1961. May 4. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by MUDHOLKAR, J.-In this appeal

facts.text: Appellants and their father Nand Singh were displaced persons from West Pakistan.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants and their father Nand Singh were displaced persons from West Pakistan and got allotment

facts.text: Appellants 1 to 3 allotted 8-1/3 standard acres of land on quasi-permanent basis in village Raikot, District Ludhiana.

anchor.surface_text: Later, each of the appellants 1 to 3 was allotted 8-1/3 standard acres of land on a quasi-permanent basis while Nail

facts.text: Nand Singh entitled to 41 standard acres and 7 units, temporarily allotted in Raikot, later allotted same in village Hambran 25-30 miles from Raikot.

anchor.surface_text: Singh, their father who was entitled to 41 standard acres and 7 units and to whom land to that extent had been temporarily allotted

facts.text: Nand Singh made application for revising the order allotting land in Hambran.

anchor.surface_text: Nand Singh made an application for revising the order under which this was done but he died

facts.text: Nand Singh died in the year 1951 during pendency of revision application.

anchor.surface_text: but he died in the year 1951, during the pendency of that application. The appellants as his legal representatives

facts.text: Appellants continued the revision application as legal representatives of Nand Singh.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants as his legal representatives continued the application. That application was rejected

facts.text: Revision application against rejection was rejected on ground that after July 22, 1952 Additional Custodian not competent to cancel allotment except per r.14(6).

anchor.surface_text: and revision application made against the order passed thereunder was also rejected on the ground that after July 22, 1952

facts.text: Respondents 4 to 9 owned lands in Chak No. 127, G.B. Jaranwala, District Lyallpur and are displaced persons.

anchor.surface_text: Respondents 4 to 9 owned lands in Chak No. 127, G. B. Jaranwala, District Lyallpur and are also displaced persons.

facts.text: Respondents 4 to 9 allotted certain lands in village Karodian as quasi-permanent allottees.

anchor.surface_text: They were, therefore, allotted certain lands in the village Karodian as quasi-permanent allottees.

facts.text: Revenue papers from Pakistan showed respondents 4-9 entitled to urban allotment.

anchor.surface_text: Subsequently some revenue papers were received from Pakistan from which it appeared that they were entitled to urban allotment.

facts.text: Deputy Commissioner exercising powers of Deputy Custodian cancelled allotment of respondents 4-9 in 1952.

anchor.surface_text: They, therefore, brought this matter before the Deputy Commissioner exercising the powers of Deputy Custodian. Thereupon he cancelled

facts.text: Deputy Custodian proposed to Additional Custodian for allotment of Karodian lands originally allotted to respondents to others.

anchor.surface_text: the allotment in their favour sometime in the year 1952 and proposed to the Additional Custodian, who was also acting

facts.text: Appellant No. 2 Gopal Singh applied on behalf of father Nand Singh to shift allotment from Hambran to Karodian.

anchor.surface_text: Appellant No. 2, Gopal Singh, on behalf of his father Nand Singh applied to the Director of Relief and Rehabilitation

facts.text: Additional Custodian allowed application of Gopal Singh, shifted Nand Singh's allotment to Karodian and also shifted appellants 1-3 from Raikot to Karodian.

anchor.surface_text: The Additional Custodian not only allowed the Application of Gopal Singh and shifted the allotment of Nand Singh to the village Karodian but

facts.text: Appellants obtained possession of Karodian lands.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants thereupon obtained possession of the Karodian lands.

facts.text: Respondents 4-9 allotted urban lands, more valuable and superior quality according to appellants.

anchor.surface_text: Respondents 4 to 9 were allotted urban lands, which according to the appellants are more valuable and are of a superior quality.

facts.text: Respondents 4-9 did not prefer application for review of cancellation or allotment to appellants.

anchor.surface_text: They did not prefer an application for review of the order of cancellation of their earlier allotment or of the order passed

facts.text: Six months later, respondents 4-9 applied to Additional Custodian that their abandoned land was rural and allotment shifted back to Karodian, without making appellants parties.

anchor.surface_text: Six months later, however, respondents 4 to 9 preferred an application before the Additional Custodian stating therein that the land abandoned

facts.text: Additional Custodian held he could not cancel appellants' allotment per r.14(6), recommended to Custodian General by memo dated October 14, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: The Additional Custodian held that he could not cancel the allotment in favour of the appellants in view of r. 14 6  of the Evacuee Property Rules

facts.text: Deputy Custodian General sent case back to Additional Custodian, observing restoration would cause chain of cancellations and Custodian General also incompetent.

anchor.surface_text: The Deputy Custodian General who heard the case sent it back to the Additional Custodian observing therein that if the respondents 4 to 9

facts.text: Additional Custodian thereafter heard application of respondents 4-9 on merits and dismissed it.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter the Additional Custodian heard the application of the respondents 4 to 9 on merits and dismissed it.

facts.text: Respondents 4-9 preferred revision before Custodian General against dismissal.

anchor.surface_text: Against his order dismissing the application respondents 4 to 9 preferred a revision application before the Custodian General.

facts.text: Deputy Custodian General granted revision, set aside allotment in favour of appellants.

anchor.surface_text: Curiously enough the Deputy Custodian General, who heard it, this time granted the application and set aside the allotment

facts.text: Appellants moved Punjab High Court under Art. 226, petition dismissed by single Judge.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants thereafter moved the High Court of Punjab under Art. 226 of the Constitution. The matter went up before a single Judge

facts.text: Letters Patent Appeal No. 38 of 1955 dismissed by Division Bench of Punjab High Court.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants thereupon preferred an appeal under the Letters Patent which was also dismissed by a Division Bench of the High Court.

facts.text: Supreme Court allows appeal, quashes orders of High Court and Deputy Custodian General.

anchor.surface_text: Accordingly we allow the appeal with costs and quash the orders of the High Court as well as of the Deputy Custodian General.

issues.text: whether after July 22, 1952 the Custodian of Evacuee Property in the State of Punjab or the Custodian General hearing an appeal from an order made by the Custodian after July 22, 1952 has the power to cancel an allotment of rural evacuee property on a quasi-permanent basis except upon the grounds set out in r. 14 6 of the Administration of Evacuee Property Rules, 1950 as amended by notification No. R. 0. 1290 dated July 22, 1952

anchor.surface_text: the question which arises for consideration is whether after July 22, 1952 the Custodian of Evacuee Property in the State of Punjab of the Custodian General hearing an appeal from an order made by the Custodian after July 22, 1952 has the power to cancel an allotment of rural evacuee property on a quasi-permanent basis except upon the grounds set out in r. 14  6

issues.text: whether the provisions of r. 14 6 did not preclude the Deputy Custodian General from exercising the powers conferred upon him by s. 27 of the Administration of Evacuee Property Act

anchor.surface_text: the provisions of r. 14  6   did not preclude the Deputy Custodian General from exercising the powers conferred upon him by s. 27 of the Administration of Evacuee Property Act

issues.text: whether the amended sub-r. 6 of r. 14 abrogates the inherent power of the Custodian to cancel an allotment for making restitution

anchor.surface_text: No doubt it is one of the highest duties of all courts to take care that the act of the court does not do injury to suitors but the court must have power to rectify the wrong. Such power may either inhere in the Court or may be expressly conferred by statute. The law does not confer any express power on the Custodian to make restitution. But we will assume that he had inherent power to do so.

issues.text: whether the limitations placed by the present sub-r. 6 of r. 14 affect the power of the Custodian General under s.27

issues.text: whether r.14(6) places any bar to the cancellation of allotments made after July 22, 1952

anchor.surface_text: The matter went up before a single Judge of the High Court who dismissed the petition observing as follows If the order of cancellation against the present opposite parties was made after the 22nd July, 1952, the order was inoperative in view of Rule 14  6  and if it be said that the order of allotment was after the date then Rule 14  6  is number bar to the cancellation of the order.

issues.text: whether this subrule can take away the wide powers conferred upon the Custodian by s. 10 of the Act

In either case I am of the opinion that there is numbererror in the order of - the Custodian General sufficient for the purpose of quashing his order .

arguments.court_reasoning: Not relied upon in statement of case; appellants not given opportunity to respond

arguments.claim: Amended sub-r.6 of r.14 abrogates or restricts inherent power of Custodian to cancel allotments for restitution as it limits cancellations to specified grounds only

anchor.surface_text: No doubt it is one of the highest duties of all courts to take care that the act of the court does number do injury to suitors but the court must have power to rectify the wrong. Such power may either inhere in the Court or may be expressly conferred by statute. ... Making of restitution is number within the exceptions and, therefore, it will have to, be said that the inherent power of the Custodian to cancel an allotment for making restitution has been abrogated by the amended sub- rule.

arguments.qualifiers: we will assume that he had inherent power

arguments.claim: Custodian General's power under s.27 to review legality/propriety does not extend to doing what subordinate Custodian or District Judge prohibited from doing by rules like r.14(6)

anchor.surface_text: the provisions of r. 14 6 did number preclude the Deputy Custodian General from exercising the powers conferred upon him by s. 27 ... He has numberpower to do something which the Custodian or District Judge companyld number have done or was prohibited from doing. Clearly, therefore, the High Court was in error in holding that the limitations placed by the present sub-r. 6 of r. 14 did number affect the power of the Custodian General.

arguments.claim: Sub-r.6 of r.14 applies to all quasi-permanent rural allotments post-July 22, 1952, barring cancellation except on enumerated grounds

anchor.surface_text: Here we have the notification dated July 22, 1952 which substituted the present sub-r. 6 of r. 14 for the original sub-r. 6. The amended sub-rule has placed a limitation on the powers of the Custodian to cancel allotment of rural evacuee property on a quasi-permanent basis. The result is that an allotment of such land can be cancelled only in the circumstances specified in that sub-rule.

arguments.claim: Rules under s.56(2)(i) validly limit powers under s.10 as expressly contemplated

anchor.surface_text: No doubt s. 10 confers wide powers on the Custodian but the opening words of the section show that the powers conferred thereby are subject to the provisions of rules, made under the Act and s. 56 2 i enables the Central Government to make rules to provide for circumstances in which leases and allotments may be cancelled or terminated

holdings.text: After July 22, 1952, the Custodian of Evacuee Property or the Custodian General does not have the power to cancel an allotment of rural evacuee property on a quasi-permanent basis except upon the grounds set out in r. 14(6) of the Administration of Evacuee Property Rules, 1950 as amended.

anchor.surface_text: under Art. 133(1)(c) of the Constitution the question which arises for consideration is whether after July 22, 1952 the Custodian of Evacuee Property

holdings.reasoning_summary: Amended sub-rule 14(6) explicitly limits cancellation powers to enumerated grounds; applies prospectively to all such allotments post-amendment; High Court erred in holding otherwise.

holdings.text: The amended sub-rule 14(6) abrogates the inherent power of the Custodian to cancel allotments for the purpose of making restitution.

anchor.surface_text: No doubt it is one of the highest duties of all courts to take care that the act of the court does not do injury to suitors but the court must have power to rectify the wrong. Such power may either inhere in the Court or may be expressly conferred by statute.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Assumes inherent power exists but holds statutory amendment restricts or removes it where not fitting specified exceptions; restitution not among permitted grounds.

holdings.text: Provisions of r.14(6) preclude the Deputy Custodian General from exercising powers under s.27 to cancel allotments prohibited for subordinate authorities.

anchor.surface_text: the provisions of r. 14(6) did not preclude the Deputy Custodian General from exercising the powers conferred upon him by s. 27 of the Administration of Evacuee Property Act

holdings.reasoning_summary: Revisional jurisdiction under s.27 limited to legality/propriety of subordinate orders; cannot empower prohibited actions or exceed subordinate limits.

holdings.text: Limitations of r.14(6) affect the power of the Custodian General under s.27.

anchor.surface_text: s. 27 of the Act provides that the Custodian General may call for the record of any proceeding in which a District Judge or a Custodian has passed an order for the purpose of satisfying himself as to the legality or propriety

holdings.reasoning_summary: Custodian General cannot authorize or perform acts prohibited to Custodian/District Judge by rules.

holdings.text: Sub-rule 14(6) validly limits wide powers under s.10 of the Act as authorized by s.56(2)(i).

anchor.surface_text: Learned counsel then contended that this subrule cannot take away the wide powers conferred upon the Custodian by s. 10 of the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.10 powers expressly subject to rules; s.56 empowers rule-making on allotment cancellations.

holdings.text: Court will not consider grounds not raised in the statement of case.

anchor.surface_text: Since the respondents have not relied upon this ground in the statement of their case we are not prepared to consider it. There may be more than one answer to the point urged by the respondents and had they specifically raised it

holdings.reasoning_summary: Procedural fairness; parties not given opportunity to respond to new arguments.

anchor.surface_text: No doubt it is one of the highest duties of all courts to take care that the act of the court does not do injury to suitors but the court must have power to rectify the wrong. Such power may either inhere in the Court or may be expressly conferred by statute.
